grounding: The use of repeated, momentary, real-world assessment methods known as the Experience Sampling Method and Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) has been broadly embraced over the last few decades. These methods have extended our assessment reach beyond lengthy retrospective self-reports as they can capture everyday experiences in their immediate context, including affect, behavior, symptoms, and cognitions. In this review we evaluate nine conceptual, methodological, and psychometric issues about EMA with the goal of stimulating conversation and guiding future research on these matters: the extent to which participants are actually reporting momentary experiences, respondents’ interpretation of momentary questions, the use of comparison standards in responding, efforts to increase the EMA reporting period beyond the moment to longer periods within a day, training of EMA study participants, concerns about selection bias of respondents, the impact of missing EMA assessments, the reliability of momentary data, and for which purposes EMA might be considered a gold standard for assessment. Resolution of these issues should have far-reaching implications for advancing the field.
generated_text: Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) has emerged as a robust method for capturing real-time data in natural settings, offering insights into the dynamics of behavior and experience. However, several pressing issues challenge its widespread application and interpretability. This review evaluates key concerns, including content validity, the establishment of gold standards, participant training, data missingness, reliability, and selection bias. The lack of standardized training protocols can lead to inconsistencies in data collection, while missing data can introduce bias and reduce the reliability of findings. Moreover, the absence of clear comparison standards complicates the validation of EMA measures. This paper synthesizes current literature to highlight these issues and proposes strategies to enhance the methodological rigor of EMA studies, ensuring more accurate and generalizable results.
